title: Enable TLS in Oracle
content:
This topic provides information on enabling TLS in Oracle database on a Linux environment.

You may skip this topic, if you are using CA signed certificates, self signed CA certificates, if you are aware of configuring TLS on Oracle server, or if you do not require TLS.

If the database is present on any other environment, for example, Windows, you must work with your Database Administrator (DBA) to complete the required setup and configurations.

For Configuring SSL/TLS on ORACLE RAC you must refer to Oracle’s documentation.

TLS configuration 

You can follow one of the following methods to create an auto_login wallet to configure TLS for an Oracle database on a Linux host. 

Example to create certificate using cdfcert tool to configure TLS

  1.  On the control plane node, run the cdfcert tool for Oracle to generate cdf_ca.crt, oracle_server.key, and oracle_server.crt: 
    cdfcert cert create oracle_server -S <Oracle hostname> -d .
  2. Copy the newly created certificates to the Oracle database server.
  3. Run the following command to change the onwership and permission of all the certificates: 
    chown oracle:oinstall <path to your certificate>

chmod +x <path to your certificate>
    where,

    <path to your certificate>: path to the certificate file.
     
  4. Create an openssl wallet to merge the oracle_server.key, oracle_server.crt, and cdf_ca.crt in pkcs12 format:  
    openssl pkcs12 -export -out wallet1.p12 -inkey <path to your oracle key> -in <path to your oracle crt> -certfile <path to your oracle ca crt>
    For a custom root CA certificate: 
    openssl pkcs12 -export -out wallet1.p12 -inkey <path to your oracle key> -in <path to your oracle crt> -certfile <path to your root ca crt>

    where,

    <path to your oracle key>:  path to the oracle_server.key
    <path to your oracle crt>: path to the oracle_server.crt
    <path to your oracle ca crt>: path to the cdf_ca.crt
    <path to your root ca crt>: path to the root_ca.crt
     
  5. Create an Oracle Wallet: 
     orapki wallet create -wallet <path to your wallet directory> -auto_login
    where,

    <path to your Wallet directory>: full path to the wallet folder.
    For example:  /u01/app/oracle/product/19.3.0/dbhome_1/owm/wallet
     
  6. Check the contents of the Wallet:

    orapki wallet display -wallet <path to your Wallet directory>

    Example: 
    orapki wallet display -wallet "/u01/app/oracle/product/19.3.0/dbhome_1/owm/wallet"
  7. Import the openssl wallet content into the Oracle Wallet with the password: 
     orapki wallet import_pkcs12 -wallet <path to your Oracle Wallet directory> -pwd <password> -pkcs12file wallet1.p12 -pkcs12pwd <password>
  8. Before you deploy, create a wallet.zip:
    zip -r wallet.zip <path to your Wallet directory>
    Example: 
    zip -r  wallet.zip /u01/app/oracle/product/19.3.0/dbhome_1/owm/wallet
  9. If you are deploying using CLI, you must store the base64 value of the wallet.zip file you created into a text file. You must pass the path of the encoded wallet text file and the path of the server certificate in the install command. BVD requires the <encoded wallet text file> and IDM and AutoPass requires the server certificate.

    Store the base64 value of this wallet.zip file into a text file: 
    base64: base64 wallet.zip > <encoded wallet text file> 


    Example:

    base64 wallet.zip > oracle_wallet_base64.txt

Update Oracle configuration files

Update the hostname, port, Oracle Wallet path, and other required values in the listener.ora and sqlnet.ora files. These files are located in the /u01/app/oracle/product/19.3.0/dbhome_1/network/admin directory.

To update the configuration:
  1. Update the configuration in listener.ora:

    LISTENER = (ADDRESS_LIST= (ADDRESS=(PROTOCOL=tcps)(HOST=servername)(PORT=2484)))
    WALLET_LOCATION=(SOURCE=(METHOD=FILE)(METHOD_DATA=(DIRECTORY=/server/wallet/path/)))
    SSL_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION=FALSE

  2. Extra configuration in sqlnet.ora:
    WALLET_LOCATION=(SOURCE=(METHOD=FILE)(METHOD_DATA=(DIRECTORY=/server/wallet/path/)))
    SSL_CLIENT_AUTHENTICATION=FALSE
  3. Restart the listener for the changes to get reflected:
    lsnrctl stop
    lsnrctl start
